title: Five and Dime
descriptions:
In Depression-era 1933, in the small prairie town of Red Willow, the local five-and-dime store serves as both lifeline and crossroads. Owned by flinty but fair widow Alma Grady, the shop keeps its lights on through layaway sales, penny candy, and Alma’s quiet habit of extending credit no one can afford to take. Her clerk, bright-eyed Ruthie Marsh, dreams of art school in Chicago but is tied to home by her out-of-work father and a secret she carries for her brother, a drifter who vanished after a freight-yard scuffle.

When slick traveling salesman Eddie Pike breezes in peddling “modern conveniences,” he promises prosperity with a new line of cheap goods—if Alma signs a predatory contract. He charms Ruthie and dazzles townsfolk hungry for hope, but Alma smells a trap. Meanwhile, farm foreclosures and breadlines gnaw at the town’s dignity, and the store’s back counter becomes a confessional: a teacher pawns her brooch, a farmer trades eggs for shoe polish, and a shy boy pockets a tin whistle he can’t pay for.

A crisis hits when the bank threatens to seize the store over Alma’s collateralized mortgage. Eddie offers a bailout in exchange for control, revealing his plan to gut the shop and turn it into a discount depot that would crush local merchants. Ruthie, torn between escape and loyalty, rallies the community. They organize a “nickel night,” pooling small change and barter to meet the note. As word spreads, Ruthie’s missing brother returns, clearing his name and bringing wages from a New Deal road crew.

On the deadline day, townspeople line the counter, placing nickels, buttons, IOUs, and stories. The sum—uneven and humble—proves enough. Eddie departs, exposed. Alma keeps the lights on, Ruthie earns her ticket to Chicago, and the five-and-dime remains what it always was: a sanctuary where small things, shared, become a lifeline.
